column2: Please confirm that the participant has received and signed the consent form.
column3: Can you explain what you know about compost (e.g. Definition, what it is used for etc.)?
column4: Compost is beneficial for your soil and crops. Do you agree with this statement?
column5: Would you be willing to use compost on your fields?
column6: Why would you like to use it on your fields? What are your expectations?
column7: How much compost would you need in a year? [kg]
column8: What do you think are advantages of compost over inorganic fertilizer?
column9: What do you think are advantages of inorganic fertilizer over compost?
column10: Do you think plants can grow good enough if you only supply them with compost?
column11: Would you be willing to use it if it is for free?
column12: How much would you be willing to pay for a 50 kg bag of compost? [MWK]
column13: What motivated you to join this visit to the composting facility?
column14: What specific aspects of the composting process were the most interesting for you?
column15: Which part of the composting process or aspect of compost itself surprised you the most?
column16: Please rate the educational value of the visit (5 = valuable / 1 = poor)
column17: What key information did you learn on the tour through the composting facility?
column18: Based on what you have learned, are you interested in implementing composting on your farm?
column19: Why do you want to start a composting? What are your reasons?
column20: What resources or support would you need to realize it?
column21: Where do you see the biggest challenges?
column22: How beneficial do you think it would be to your farm if you started composting?
column23: Based on what you have learned, are you interested in participating in a community compost project with other farmers?
column24: Why do you want to participate in a community compost project? What are your reasons?
column25: How many hours per week would you be willing to help?
column26: Do you expect any reimbursements for your participation?
column27: What kind of reimbursement do you expect (e.g. free compost / money others)
column28: What resources or support would be needed to realize such a project?
column29: What factors (e.g. people participating) would influence your decision to participate in such a project?
column30: Where do you see the biggest challenges?
column31: How beneficial do you think would a community compost project be for your farming activities?
column32: In your opinion how would a community compost project look like? What are key elements that it can be a success?
column33: Would you be willing to take a leading role in such a project?
column34: Describe the responsibilities you would be willing to take.
column35: Who (organization or person) would be a good fit to take the leading role for such a project?
column36: What barriers or concerns do you have regarding a participation in a community compost project?
column37: Would you be interested in attending additional workshop or training session on composting?
column38: In your opinion, what do you think would be the most suitable way for you to learn composting?
column39: Do you see a potential business opportunity for you in the field of composting?
column40: Can you please explain it a bit more?
column41: Can you please explain why you do not see a business opportunity? What are the hurdles, issues, limitations?
column42: After learning about compost today, did your perception changed about using compost on your field?
column43: Can you please elaborate what has changed?
column44: After learning about compost today, did your perception changed about using compost on your field?
column45: Do you have any final remarks?

column3: It's manure making process that uses animal manure and leafs. It piles waste. The piles are 2 by 2 meters. You soak the waste. Use 3 wheel barrows of manure. If we making compost in rainy season it needs a shed. In summer you don't need a shed

column8: Compost doesn't depletes soil. It makes land Sustainable than inorganic fertilizer that our children will be able to use
column9: It's fast and works. But only damages the soils

column14: How to use compost and the distancing of plants when using compost. We were to know how different crops behaviour in soil. To take out week crops.
column15: Planting of maize when using compost. Maize needs to be in line. If the lining is not okay, then maize will respond differently to compost/manure
column17: Planting and spacing of maize in a specified line of 60 cm. FUZUZA type of planting

column3: Compost can be made of any biodegradable things. We take dead leaves, put manure then - 4 wheelbarrow. You need fresh plants to provide energy for the bacteria. Compost needs air for the bacteria. You need to turn the piles three times. It takes 8 weeks to make Compost. You sieve manure after 8 weeks. Things which didn't break can then used again for the next Compost. The size of Compost is 2×2×2 meters
column6: To restore our depleted soils. It's cheap so can manage to use and improve yield
column8: Compost is cheap, restores soil. With time it lessen use of compost that we may even plant crops with manure/compost
column9: It improves yield but depletes soil

column14: Use of urine in compost making and that urine works as Urea fertilizer

column17: Compost looks like unimportant, but if you can put effort and start making Compost you can benefit alot by increasing yield

column3: Compost is manure made from biodegradable waste. It takes 4 months to make. You take dry leaves and soil, then add green leaves and add soil, then add manure add soils. You repeat the process.  It can be 4cm or 8 cm. It can be used as fertilizer for maize, tomatoes

column8:

It brings microbes in the soil essential for crop production
column9: It's works as the yield is high. You are guaranteed of harvesting high yield

column3: I can make compost on my own without challenges. Compost need biodegradable waste for example dead leaves, animal manure. You piles waste, dry leaves, then green leaves and manure. The pile needs to be mixed and turned every week. You add or spray water. It takes 2 monts to makes. It's 2x2

column8: It restores soil nutrients. You even get yield even if you fail to apply once soil has regained it's nutrients. It's cheap as it uses local resources

column15: I didn't know that termites don't eat fresh thing. They only only eat dry things. So when you put compost and mulch the field, you are assured that termites won't eat your crops

column43: Compost works as NPK for basal dressing. You apply compost in a hole, then cover and put compost. You can keep urine for 3 weeks and use it for top dressing. Urine of 500 milliliters can used as a top dressing when using compost. This urine should be applied 2 times per growing season. 1 : 3 urine to water ratio is used for this type of liquid fertilizer
column44: Definitely, I'm excited to start composting!

column3: Compost is made of biodegradable waste as well as animal manure. You pile the waste and turn the waste. You use fresh grass, dry grass. You spray water on the pile. You need 4 wheelbarrows of animal manure for each layer. You start piling by dry grass, then green grass, and then animal manure. Then you repeat the process. You can use compost on maize, rice, tomato, vegetables.
